bibl.title: Telegram from John A. Ferrell to Laura Armistead Carter, September 14, 1925

div1.p: Ferrell offers his condolences on the death of Henry Carter. He expresses appreciation for Henry Carter's work and his humanity.

div1.head: Telegram from John A. Ferrell to Laura Armistead Carter, September 14, 1925
div1.opener:
Form 1220
WESTERN UNION
WESTERN UNION
TELEGRAM
NEWCOMB CARLTON, PRESIDENT
GEORGE W. E. ATKINS. FIRST VICE-PRESIDENT
__________________________________________________
The filing time as shown in the date line on full-rate telegrams and day letters, and the time of receipt at destination as shown on all messages, is STANDARD TIME.
Received at
24 1WGW 131 BLUE
CO NEW YORK NY 218P SEPT 14 1925
MISS LAURA CARTER
div1.p:
EXTEND TO YOU AND FAMILY PROFOUNDEST SYMPATHY STOP THE LOSS
OF YOUR FATHER IS A LOSS TO THE CAUSE OF
PUBLIC HEALTH OF AN OUTSTANDING LEADER STOP THE REMARKABLE BREADTH
AND ACCURATENESS OF HIS KNOWLEDGE HIS SOUND JUDGMENT UNTIRING ENERGY
CAPACITY DEVOTION AND CONSIDERATION OF HIS COLLEAGUES ESPECIALLY HIS SUBORD-
INATES HAS ENDEARED HIM TO AN UNRIVALED DEGREE TO A GREAT HOST
OF ASSOCIATES AND ADMIRERS STOP HIS LEADERSHIP IN THE SUCCESSFUL
WARFARE ON YELLOW FEVER IN THIS AND OTHER COUNTRIES OF THE
WORLD AND HIS WORK IN THE CONTROL OF MALARIA
AND IN OTHER SANITARY ADVANCES COMBINED WITH HIS LOVABLE PERSONAL
QUALITIES OF SINCERITY FRIENDLINESS FRANKNESS SIMPLICITY AND AN
ABSENCE OF INTEREST IN RANK GLORY OR RECOGNITION FOR HIMSELF WILL
MAKE HIM AN OUTSTANDING FIGURE IN THE HISTORY OF DISEASE CONTROL
